title: Archive through January 07, 2004
content: It's not Alchemy from Jeremy Tankard... I'm curious on this ID ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
author: adriano

comments.content: Not Barnbrook or Tankard (hint: wrong gender)
Is it a Cyrillic face?

Margo Chase 's Edit?   
   
 [http://www.t26.com/fonts/display.php?f\_id=443](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/display.php?f_id=443)

no sorry Margo Chase 's Shiraz?   
   
 [http://www.t26.com/fonts/display.php?f\_id=449&dw=1943](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/display.php?f_id=449&dw=1943)
Yep, Shiraz is the one. Go Peter.
![HAPPY NEW YEAR](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23262.gif)

hehehe   
   
oki here's tonights quiz:   
 ![quizzylizzy](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23311.gif)   
   
   
Name the typeface.   
   
Good luck!

well you never know with you guys (i mean after seeing excellent Justin Callaghan's Happy New Year quiz)   
   
i bet Bruhn has done something similar tricky here... so i am guessing this is the number 2 but backwards   
   
how about that?! : )
{edit} doubleposted..

It could well be a ct ligature, but it doesn't look like Baskerville 1757 to me: the top isn't monolinear enough, and the ball terminal is too heavy. [Next time I see Lars I must ask him if he was inspired in his naming by our Garamond 1530.]

Yves: yes it's an italic ligature, but not a "ct"   
No it's nothing by Lars (or from any other font in the Fountain c library)   
   
here's a little more:   
 ![qqq](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23320.gif)
How about the "ch" ligature from [DTL Fleischmann italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659/http:/www.dutchtypelibrary.nl/FleischmannAltItalic.html)?

Sigh! why can't I ever come up with tricky questions ;)   
Congrats! Yes, your are right Addison.   
Now, Let's hope you can come up with something more difficult than my quiz :-D

Cool! Fleischmann is one of my favorites -- the guys at DTL have created some exquisite work.   
   
This one may be a little obscure, but try it out:   
   
 ![glyph](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23330.gif)
Yep. It's a percent glyph.
Something from Storm?
It is from the Storm Type Foundry -- one of his italics...
Antique Moderne Italic?

Ding, ding, ding! You got it, Adriano. Mr. Storm has a beautiful touch:   
   
 ![Storm percent glyph](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23348.gif)   
[STF Antique Moderne Italic]   
   
Oh, and Mr. Bruhn, just to let you know, I spent an entire morning looking up your glyph. It wasn't easy at all.   
   
Your turn, Adriano.
Alright, I've got to jet right now, but I'll be back in a few hours.
I don't think that was originally designed as a percent sign: it looks like a 'care of' sign, such as one uses in sending a letter c/o a third person.

You probably know this, Mr. Hudson, but here's a brief [origin of the percent sign](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659/http:/www.roma.unisa.edu.au/07305/symbols.htm#Percent). (not sure how credible that info is)   
   
I guess Mr. Storm used a little creative license. Perhaps the "c" is for "centum."   
   
No, I think you're right. In the roman font there's a standard percent symbol, but I guess he intended for the italic to be used as "care of." How about that...

Here we go, then.   
   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23405.gif)

OK, I'm guessin' this time around . . .   
   
I say Helvetica Ultra Light Ampersand . . .   
   
:D

Helvetica, no.   
Ampersand, yes.
DeGroot?
Negative on that.
is it a script?

Not a script.   
I'm going to bed now... I'll post either another detail or a hint tomorrow.   
Good night typophiles ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
Jeremy Tankard's Aspect Light?

No, it isn't Aspect either.   
   
Here's another detail of the same glyph.   
   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23442.gif)
Apex

Correct! It's the Apex ampersand (both sans and serif are identical).   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23445.gif)   
   
   
Take it, BJ!

thanks Adriano.   
   
i'll post one in the morning.   
   
   
bj

"[STF Antique Moderne Italic] "   
   
And I who thought i went thorughly through the Storm Catalogu on that percentage quiz :-D
BTW, his Jannon Antiqua also has an amazing percent sign.

At MyFonts.com: [Jannon Antiqua Italic percent](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/jannon/ant-osf-italic/mac-t1/146771/character/0025/CP4/1/)   
   
You're right, that's pretty amazing. Concerning the "care of" sign that Mr. Hudson mentioned above, I'd like to know if that's what Storm intended.   
   
I came across the percent sign while looking at Moderne Antique Italic in TypeTool. I haven't seen it anywhere else.

Name 4 of the 8 glyphs   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23484.jpg)
Is the fourth one Swedish?
United States
No. 6 is from a Swedish designer ![:-O](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/proud.gif)

#3 - Tractor   
#5 - Forkbeard   
#7 - Delphin   
#8 - Madrone

FWIW:   
2. Hrant's Daam Entity   
6. Filt

Adriano, you got it!   
   
#1 Hamburger Heaven, Nick Curtis   
#2 Brutaal, hhp   
#3 Tractor, Martin Wait   
#4 Curbdog Italic, TPC   
#5 Forkbeard, Michael Gills   
#6, Filt, Martin Fredrickson   
#7, Delphin I, Georg Trump   
#8, Madrone, Barbara Lind

Here we go again!   
   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23495.gif)

Adriano, maybe a clue before you retire for the evening?   
Could it be Blackletter? Your crop is supertight.

It is a dollar sign, it is not a blackletter.   
   
Still a few more hours until I go to bed. I will post a hint or another detail of the glyph before I go.

I'm off to bed now, here's another image (same glyph).   
   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518122659im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23523.gif)
